Home >SkyBridge® ProxyDLL > More Details
The end-to-end process of generating the proxy DLLs
The end-to-end process of calling a function in proxy DLL C’ when the freelancer runs the project
Other use cases

When the freelancer runs the project, a function in proxy DLL C’ is called. Following is the end-to-end process:

  1. Function “GetEmployeeBirthday” in proxy DLL C’ is called with input parameter “EmployeeId” being “12345”.
2. This function assembles the following XML string: 
   <FunctionName>GetEmployeeBirthday</FunctionName>
   <InputParams>
     <Param Name=”EmployeeId” Type=”int”>12345</Param>
</InputParams>
  1. This function passes the XML on to the SkyBridge ProxyDLL client.
  2. The client checks if the end user has turned on caching for this function. If yes, and there is a cached value that has not expired, return the cached value to the function, and the function returns the value to the caller. This is the end of the function call.
  3. If there is no cached value, the client sends this XML via the SkyBridge® instant remoting to the client in the PC in the software house that contains the original DLLs.
  4. The client calls function “GetEmployeeBirthday” in the original DLL C with input parameter “EmployeeId” being “12345”
  5. That function returns “23/07/1987” as the birthday to the client.
  6. The client returns “23/07/1987” via the SkyBridge® instant remoting to the client in the freelancer’s PC.
  7. The client in the freelancer’s PC returns “23/07/1987” to the function in proxy DLL C.
  8. The function returns “23/07/1987” to the caller.

The whole process takes less than half a second, and end user does not need to know anything about it. All they know is that function “GetEmployeeBirthday” in the proxy DLL C’ was called with input parameter “EmployeeId” being “12345”, and it returned “23/07/1987” in 121 milliseconds.
